meanings.definition: To deprive (a nerve or organ) of its nerve supply.
meanings.sent1: The surgery will denervate the affected area, reducing sensation.
meanings.sent2: The dentist had to denervate the tooth before performing the procedure.
meanings.sent3: After the accident, the clumsy magician managed to denervate his own hand.
meanings.sent4: The relentless cold seemed to denervate the trees, leaving them bare and lifeless.
meanings.sent5: The poison ivy's effect on my skin seemed to denervate the area, making it numb.

meanings.definition: To remove the nerve supply from (a part of the body).
meanings.sent1: The disease can denervate the muscles, causing weakness.
meanings.sent2: The surgeon had to denervate the damaged nerve to prevent further pain.
meanings.sent3: The mischievous cat managed to denervate the toy mouse, rendering it motionless.
meanings.sent4: The storm's fury seemed to denervate the power lines, leaving the town in darkness.
meanings.sent5: The frostbite appeared to denervate my fingers, making them tingle and numb.

meanings.definition: To cause loss of nerve function in (a body part).
meanings.sent1: The medication may denervate the affected limb, leading to temporary paralysis.
meanings.sent2: The injury could denervate the hand, affecting its ability to move.
meanings.sent3: The prankster's fake spider managed to denervate my friend's arm, causing a moment of panic.
meanings.sent4: The eerie silence seemed to denervate the room, making everyone uneasy.
meanings.sent5: The spider's venom appeared to denervate the prey, immobilizing it completely.
